title: Erdős Problem #400: Factorial Divisibility and Sum Excess
description: For k ≥ 2, let g_k(n) = max{(a₁+⋯+aₖ)-n : a₁!⋯aₖ! | n!}. Is Σ g_k(n) ~ cₖ·x·log x? Is g_k(n) concentrated around cₖ·log x? OPEN.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős and Graham (1980, p. 77) studied g_k(n), the maximum excess of a₁ + ⋯ + aₖ over n subject to a₁!⋯aₖ! | n!. They proved g_k(n) = O(log n) but the precise asymptotics remain unknown.
overview.problemStatement: For k ≥ 2, let g_k(n) = max{(a₁+⋯+aₖ) - n : a₁!⋯aₖ! ∣ n!}. (a) Is Σ_{n≤x} g_k(n) ~ cₖ · x · log x? (b) Is g_k(n) = cₖ · log x + o(log x) for almost all n ≤ x?
overview.proofStrategy: We define FactorialDivides (the divisibility condition), sumExcess, and gExcess (the maximization). ErdosProblem400a states the average growth conjecture and ErdosProblem400b the concentration conjecture. The upper bound g_k(n) ≪ log n is axiomatized. The k = 2 case is developed with its binomial coefficient connection.
keyInsights: The condition a₁!⋯aₖ! | n! connects to multinomial coefficients
Erdős–Graham proved g_k(n) = O(log n), giving the right order of magnitude
The problem asks for precise constants cₖ and concentration phenomena
For k = 2, the problem reduces to a! · b! | n!, related to binomial coefficients

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem 400 asks for precise asymptotics of g_k(n), the maximum sum excess under factorial divisibility. The upper bound O(log n) is known but the exact constants and concentration behavior remain open.
conclusion.implications: Understanding g_k(n) would reveal the combinatorial structure of factorial divisibility, connecting to multinomial coefficients and prime factorizations.
openQuestions: Does the average Σ g_k(n) / (x log x) converge to a constant?
Is g_k(n) concentrated around its mean for almost all n?
What is the exact value of c₂ for the k = 2 case?
